comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Born 1897 London. The 1901 census records him living at 670 Old Ford Road, Bow, London, with his parents Edward [b.1863 Bethnal Green, London] and Ruth [b.1864 Holborn, London] and older sister Lilian [b.1895 Bow, London] and younger brother William [b.1900 Bow, London]. His father is employed as a Cabinet Maker.
The 1911 census records the family still living at the same address but with two additional daughters born since the 1901 census, Edith [b.1902 Bow, London] and Ruth [b.1908 Bow, London]. Albert is now fourteen years of age and employed as a Match Box Cutter.
He joined the Royal Fusiliers 32nd Btn. (City of London Regiment) Reg. No 22062
As yet, I have been unable to find his enlistment details.
The date of Albert’s death, 15th September 1916m was the date that the battle of High Wood [Bois des Forcaux] ended and the Wood was finally take. Many London battalions were engaged in this effort, so much so that the adjacent CWGC cemetery is named London Cemetary.

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Here is an overlay of the 1916 Map onto a Google Earth shot of Albert’s family home [along with a view of the site as it is now] at 670 Old Ford Road – that part of it now named Wick Lane and an industrial estate. Less than 500 meters from the new Olympic stadium.
Click on the thumbnail for a bigger view [Best viewed LARGE].
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/liits/6756363911/in/photostream]

comment.author: 68061336@N05
comment._content: The Commonwealth War Graves Commission has the following details Name: WILLIS, ALBERT Initials: A Nationality: United Kingdom Rank: Private Regiment/Service: Royal Fusiliers Unit Text: 32nd Bn. Age: 19 Date of Death: 15/09/1916 Service No: 22062 Additional information: Son of Mrs. Ruth Willis, of 670, Old Ford Rd., Bow, London. Casualty Type: Commonwealth War Dead Grave/Memorial Reference: Pier and Face 8 C 9 A and 16 A. Memorial: THIEPVAL MEMORIAL and can be found here www.cwgc.org/search/casualty_details.aspx?casualty=822397
